The **Imaginary unit**, or $i$, is the number with the following equivalent properties:

- $i^2=-1$

- $\sqrt{-1}=i$

A **complex number** is any number that can be written as $\greenD{a}+\blueD{b}i$, where $i$ is the imaginary unit and $\greenD{a}$ and $\blueD{b}$ are real numbers.

$\greenD a$ is called **the $\greenD{\text{real}}$ part** of the number, and $\blueD b$ is called **the $\blueD{\text{imaginary}}$ part** of the number.

## □□□ □□□□□□□ □□□□□

□□□□ □□□□ □□ □□□ □□□ □□□ □□□□□□ □□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□ □□□ □□□ □□ □□□□ □□□□□□□, □□ □□□ □□□ □□□ □□□□□□□ □□□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□ □□□ □□□ □□ □□□□□□□ □□□□□□□.

[[☃ image 1]]

The **complex plane** consists of two number lines that intersect in a right angle at the point $(0,0)$.   

The horizontal number line (what we know as the $x$-axis on a Cartesian plane) is the **real axis**.

The vertical number line (the $y$-axis on a Cartesian plane) is the **imaginary axis**.

##□□□□□□□□ □ □□□□□□□ □□□□□□

□□□□□ □□□□□□□ □□□□□□ □□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□□□ □□ □ □□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□□□ □□□□□.   

For example, consider the number $3-5i$.  This number, also expressed as $\greenD{3}+(\blueD{-5})i$,  has a real part of $\greenD{3}$ and an imaginary part of $\blueD{-5}$.  

The location of this number on the complex plane is the point that corresponds to $\greenD{3}$ on the real axis and $\blueD{-5}$ on the imaginary axis.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5c6c8ef22a548d2a48b2425284b62cd4029585aa)

So the number $\greenD{3}+(\blueD{-5})i$ is associated with the point $(\greenD{3}, \blueD{-5})$. In general, the complex number $\greenD a+\blueD bi$ corresponds to the point $(\greenD a,\blueD b)$ in the complex plane.

hint.content:
The number $\greenD{-4}+\blueD{7}i$,  has a real part of $\greenD{-4}$ and an imaginary part of $\blueD{7}$.  

So, to find the location of this number on the complex plane, move to the point that corresponds to $\greenD{-4}$ on the real axis and $\blueD{7}$ on the imaginary axis, or the point $(\greenD{-4}, \blueD7)$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/741dbf620c640376c28f8e02cf70398dfa581de3)

The number $6i+1$,  which can be written as $\greenD{1}+\blueD{6}i$ has a real part of $\greenD{1}$ and an imaginary part of $\blueD{6}$.  

So, to find the location of this number on the complex plane, move to the point that corresponds to $\greenD{1}$ on the real axis and $\blueD{6}$ on the imaginary axis, or the point $(\greenD1,\blueD6)$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/940b142617705fff7125a29f30f70c4eb4d10285)

The number $-i-3$,  which can be written as $\greenD{-3}+(\blueD{-1})i$ has a real part of $\greenD{-3}$ and an imaginary part of $\blueD{-1}$.  

So, to find the location of this number on the complex plane, move to the point that corresponds to $\greenD{-3}$ on the real axis and $\blueD{-1}$ on the imaginary axis, or the point $(\greenD{-3}, \blueD{-1})$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/16c51064e6893f6ed1fe70704d787f67dc62a014)

The number $4i$, which can be rewritten as $\greenD{0}+\blueD{4}i$, has a real part of $\greenD{0}$ and an imaginary part of $\blueD4$.  Therefore, the complex number is represented by the point at $(\greenD{0}, \blueD4)$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2302f823f804bcf8924802a6c325b253d1694d1f)

□□□□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□, □□ □□□ □□□□ □□□□ □□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□ □□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□□□□□ □□□□!

The number $-7$, which can be rewritten as $\greenD{-7}+\blueD{0}i$, has a real part of $\greenD{-7}$ and an imaginary part of $\blueD0$.  Therefore, the complex number is represented by the point at $(\greenD{-7}, \blueD0)$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/654db81b1714b53adc11845864229e0359b13205)

##□□□□□□□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□ □□□□□□ □□□□

In Pythagoras's days, the existence of irrational numbers was a surprising discovery!  They wondered how something like  $\sqrt{2}$ could exist without an accurate complete decimal expansion.  

The real number line, however, helps rectifying this dilemma.  Why?  Because $\sqrt{2}$ has a specific location on the real number line, showing that it is indeed a real number. (If you take the diagonal of a unit square and place one end on $0$, the other end corresponds to the number $\sqrt{2}$.)
